ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about anatomical terms, and became more aware of my body in relationship to movement.
Connecting science with movement. Anatomical terms. Useful dance knowledge
How to be more in tune with my body
I became much more aware about the anatomy of my body and started dancing more freely.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths included learning a lot about anatomy and applying this knowledge to movement. Something I wish was improved was the intensity/difficulty of the dance/movement aspect of the class. Although this class was beginner friendly, I thought it was at times too beginner friendly.
This course is great for people curious about dance, but maybe a little repetitive and tedious at times.

At first, the course was interesting and brought a fresh perspective to movement. However, as the term progressed, the classes became repetitive and meaningless, and each lesson was an hour long session of moving limbs in improvisation.

Strengths: the class was insightful and I learned a lot about my body

Weaknesses: I thought the class could have a little more structure and could incorporate more dancing since it was described as a dance class. The papers we wrote in class seemed kind of trivial, too.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but not to THST majors who are looking to improve their dance skills. This class is very dance beginner friendly, so anyone with past dance experience might not get the most out of this class.
Only recommend as an easy humanities/arts credit for people who want to dance. Not much science involved, more movement.

I would recommend it if you find psuedoscience interesting, as the "anatomy" portion of the course consists of topics such as "energy" in your mind and body or ideokinesis. It is also a fairly low pressure class as there is no intellectual challengejust a bit of physical movement and concentration.

Yes, if you're looking for a fifth class. It's not a very engaging class, and it can be boring at times, but it does not take a lot of work and the classes are relaxing. You do learn quite a bit about the human body and I think it can be very valuable.
Definitely. This course made my understand my body a lot better.
